questions.question: Thinking about the actual AI tools available to your employees today—like AI assistants or copilots—which of these statements best describes your company's environment?

options.description: No official tools are provided; we assume some use of public AI websites.
A few tools are being tested informally by a small, uncoordinated group of users.
We are running formal, approved pilots of specific AI tools for a defined business purpose.
An integrated suite of enterprise-grade AI tools is widely available and embedded in our standard workflows.

questions.question: When it comes to applying AI to solve specific business problems, which of these statements sounds most like your current approach?

options.description: We have not identified any specific business problems and have not yet connected AI to business value.
We have brainstormed potential ideas but lack a formal business case or ROI for them.
We have active pilot projects underway with clearly defined and measurable business goals.
We manage a portfolio of deployed AI solutions and actively measure their business impact.

questions.question: Regarding the data needed to power AI, which of these descriptions best fits your organization's data environment?

options.description: Our data is siloed and difficult to access, which is a major roadblock for any AI initiative.
We have foundational projects underway to improve data quality and access.
We have prepared high-quality, accessible data specifically for our current pilot projects.
We have a mature, centralized data platform that provides governed, high-quality data for enterprise use.

questions.question: How prepared is your company's underlying technology architecture to support and scale new AI applications?

options.description: Significant technical debt or legacy systems would block any new AI deployment.
We know our infrastructure needs to be upgraded for AI, but this is not yet resourced or scheduled.
Our current infrastructure supports our pilots, and we have a clear plan to scale if they are successful.
A modern, scalable cloud architecture is in place, ready to handle enterprise-grade AI workloads.

questions.question: Looking at your teams' skills and the company culture, which statement best reflects your readiness for AI-driven changes?

options.description: There are significant AI skill gaps, and the company culture is generally resistant to process changes.
Pockets of enthusiasm for AI exist, but we have no formal training or change management plan.
We have a dedicated team for our pilots and leadership support for the change.
We have established AI teams, a company-wide upskilling program, and a formal change management plan.

questions.question: Thinking about how your teams use or might use AI tools, what level of formal guidance or controls are they operating under?

options.description: Teams and individuals are using AI based on their own judgment, without any official company guidelines.
General recommendations or informal guidance have been shared, but there are no formal, documented policies.
Clear guidelines and controls have been established for specific, approved pilot projects or tools.
There is a well-understood, enterprise-wide policy for responsible AI use that is actively communicated to all teams.
